author: Potter
text: Once upon a time there was a little girl called Lucie, who lived at a farm called Little-town.

author: Potter
text: She was a good little girl--only she was always losing her pocket-handkerchiefs!

author: Potter
text: One day little Lucie came into the farm-yard crying--oh, she did cry so!

author: Potter
text: "I've lost my pocket-handkin!

author: Potter
text: Three handkins and a pinny!

author: Potter
text: Have YOU seen them, Tabby Kitten?"

author: Potter
text: The Kitten went on washing her white paws; so Lucie asked a speckled hen--

author: Potter
text: "Sally Henny-penny, have YOU found three pocket-handkins?"

author: Potter
text: But the speckled hen ran into a barn, clucking--

author: Potter
text: "I go barefoot, barefoot, barefoot!"

author: Potter
text: And then Lucie asked Cock Robin sitting on a twig.

author: Potter
text: Cock Robin looked sideways at Lucie with his bright black eye, and he flew over a stile and away.

author: Potter
text: Lucie climbed upon the stile and looked up at the hill behind Little- town--a hill that goes up--up--into the clouds as though it had no top!

author: Potter
text: And a great way up the hillside she thought she saw some white things spread upon the grass.

author: Potter
text: Lucie scrambled up the hill as fast as her short legs would carry her; she ran along a steep path-way--up and up--until Little-town was right away down below--she could have dropped a pebble down the chimney!

author: Potter
text: Presently she came to a spring, bubbling out from the hillside.

author: Potter
text: Some one had stood a tin can upon a stone to catch the water--but the water was already running over, for the can was no bigger than an egg- cup!

author: Potter
text: And where the sand upon the path was wet--there were footmarks of a VERY small person.

author: Potter
text: Lucie ran on, and on.

author: Potter
text: The path ended under a big rock.

author: Potter
text: The grass was short and green, and there were clothes-props cut from bracken stems, with lines of plaited rushes, and a heap of tiny clothes pins--but no pocket-handkerchiefs!

author: Potter
text: But there was something else--a door! straight into the hill; and inside it some one was singing--

author: Potter
text: "Lily-white and clean, oh!

author: Potter
text: With little frills between, oh!

author: Potter
text: Smooth and hot-red rusty spot Never here be seen, oh!"

author: Potter
text: Lucie knocked-once-twice, and interrupted the song.

author: Potter
text: A little frightened voice called out "Who's that?"

author: Potter
text: Lucie opened the door: and what do you think there was inside the hill?--a nice clean kitchen with a flagged floor and wooden beams-- just like any other farm kitchen.

author: Potter
text: Only the ceiling was so low that Lucie's head nearly touched it; and the pots and pans were small, and so was everything there.

author: Potter
text: There was a nice hot singey smell; and at the table, with an iron in her hand, stood a very stout short person staring anxiously at Lucie.

author: Potter
text: Her print gown was tucked up, and she was wearing a large apron over her striped petticoat.

author: Potter
text: Her little black nose went sniffle, sniffle, snuffle, and her eyes went twinkle, twinkle; and underneath her cap-where Lucie had yellow curls-that little person had PRICKLES!

author: Potter
text: "Who are you?" said Lucie.

author: Potter
text: "Have you seen my pocket-handkins?"

author: Potter
text: The little person made a bob- curtsey--"Oh yes, if you please'm; my name is Mrs. Tiggy-winkle; oh yes if you please'm, I'm an excellent clear- starcher!"

author: Potter
text: And she took something out of the clothesbasket, and spread it on the ironing-blanket.

author: Potter
text: "What's that thing?" said Lucie- "that's not my pocket-handkin?"

author: Potter
text: "Oh no, if you please'm; that's a little scarlet waist-coat belonging to Cock Robin!"

author: Potter
text: And she ironed it and folded it, and put it on one side.

author: Potter
text: Then she took something else off a clothes-horse--"That isn't my pinny?" said Lucie.

author: Potter
text: "Oh no, if you please'm; that's a damask table-cloth belonging to Jenny Wren; look how it's stained with currant wine!

author: Potter
text: It's very bad to wash!" said Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tiggy-winkle's nose went sniffle sniffle snuffle, and her eyes went twinkle twinkle; and she fetched another hot iron from the fire.

author: Potter
text: "There's one of my pocket- handkins!" cried Lucie--"and there's my pinny!"

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tiggy-winkle ironed it, and goffered it, and shook out the frills.

author: Potter
text: "Oh that IS lovely!" said Lucie.

author: Potter
text: "And what are those long yellow things with fingers like gloves?"

author: Potter
text: "Oh that's a pair of stockings belonging to Sally Henny-penny--look how she's worn the heels out with scratching in the yard!

author: Potter
text: She'll very soon go barefoot!" said Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.

author: Potter
text: "Why, there's another hankersniff-- but it isn't mine; it's red?"

author: Potter
text: "Oh no, if you please'm; that one belongs to old Mrs. Rabbit; and it DID so smell of onions!

author: Potter
text: I've had to wash it separately, I can't get out that smell."

author: Potter
text: "There's another one of mine," said Lucie.

author: Potter
text: "What are those funny little white things?"

author: Potter
text: "That's a pair of mittens belonging to Tabby Kitten; I only have to iron them; she washes them herself."

author: Potter
text: "There's my last pocket-handkin!" said Lucie.

author: Potter
text: "And what are you dipping into the basin of starch?"

author: Potter
text: "They're little dicky shirt-fronts belonging to Tom Titmouse--most terrible particular!" said Mrs. Tiggy- winkle.

author: Potter
text: "Now I've finished my ironing; I'm going to air some clothes."

author: Potter
text: "What are these dear soft fluffy things?" said Lucie.

author: Potter
text: "Oh those are woolly coats belonging to the little lambs at Skelghyl."

author: Potter
text: "Will their jackets take off?" asked Lucie.

author: Potter
text: "Oh yes, if you please'm; look at the sheep-mark on the shoulder.

author: Potter
text: And here's one marked for Gatesgarth, and three that come from Little-town.

author: Potter
text: They're ALWAYS marked at washing!" said Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.

author: Potter
text: And she hung up all sorts and sizes of clothes--small brown coats of mice; and one velvety black moleskin waist-coat; and a red tail-coat with no tail belonging to Squirrel Nutkin; and a very much shrunk blue jacket belonging to Peter Rabbit; and a petticoat, not marked, that had gone lost in the washing--and at last the basket was empty!

author: Potter
text: Then Mrs. Tiggy-winkle made tea--a cup for herself and a cup for Lucie.

author: Potter
text: They sat before the fire on a bench and looked sideways at one another.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tiggy-winkle's hand, holding the tea-cup, was very very brown, and very very wrinkly with the soap-suds; and all through her gown and her cap, there were HAIRPINS sticking wrong end out; so that Lucie didn't like to sit too near her.

author: Potter
text: When they had finished tea, they tied up the clothes in bundles; and Lucie's pocket-handkerchiefs were folded up inside her clean pinny, and fastened with a silver safety-pin.

author: Potter
text: And then they made up the fire with turf, and came out and locked the door, and hid the key under the door-sill.

author: Potter
text: Then away down the hill trotted Lucie and Mrs. Tiggy-winkle with the bundles of clothes!

author: Potter
text: All the way down the path little animals came out of the fern to meet them; the very first that they met were Peter Rabbit and Benjamin Bunny!

author: Potter
text: And she gave them their nice clean clothes; and all the little animals and birds were so very much obliged to dear Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.

author: Potter
text: So that at the bottom of the hill when they came to the stile, there was nothing left to carry except Lucie's one little bundle.

author: Potter
text: Lucie scrambled up the stile with the bundle in her hand; and then she turned to say "Good-night," and to thank the washer-woman.--But what a VERY odd thing!

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tiggy-winkle had not waited either for thanks or for the washing bill!

author: Potter
text: She was running running running up the hill--and where was her white frilled cap? and her shawl? and her gown-and her petticoat?

author: Potter
text: And HOW small she had grown-- and HOW brown--and covered with PRICKLES!

author: Potter
text: Why!

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tiggy-winkle was nothing but a HEDGEHOG! * * * * * *

author: Potter
text: (Now some people say that little Lucie had been asleep upon the stile--but then how could she have found three clean pocket-handkins and a pinny, pinned with a silver safety-pin?

author: Potter
text: And besides--I have seen that door into the back of the hill called Cat Bells--and besides _I_ am very well acquainted with dear Mrs. Tiggy-winkle!)
